name: Ghevar
history: Ghevar is a traditional Rajasthani sweet, particularly popular during the Teej and Raksha Bandhan festivals. It's known for its disc-like shape and honeycomb texture.
description: Ghevar is a crispy, sweet cake made from all-purpose flour, ghee, and milk. It's deep-fried and then soaked in sugar syrup, often topped with dry fruits, rabri, or whipped cream.

instructions.title: Prepare the Batter
instructions.description: Whisk ghee, flour, and milk together. Gradually add ice water to form a smooth, flowing batter. Optionally, add food color.

instructions.title: Fry the Ghevar
instructions.description: Heat oil in a deep pan. Pour the batter in a thin stream into the oil, forming a disc. Fry until crisp. Remove and drain excess oil.

instructions.title: Prepare Sugar Syrup
instructions.description: Boil sugar and water to make a syrup. Add saffron and cardamom. Strain the syrup.

instructions.title: Soak Ghevar in Syrup
instructions.description: Dip the fried Ghevar in sugar syrup. Remove and let excess syrup drain.

instructions.title: Garnish
instructions.description: Garnish with pistachios and silver leaf. Let it cool before serving.

tips: Maintain a consistent temperature while frying for even cooking.
The batter consistency is crucial for the right texture of Ghevar.
variations: Top with rabri or whipped cream for a richer flavor.
Experiment with different nuts or dried fruits for garnishing.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh, can be stored for 1-2 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container at room temperature.

reheatingInstructions: Typically not reheated; served at room temperature.
presentationTips: Serve on a decorative plate with a dollop of rabri or a drizzle of honey.
